title: 114_hr2104
content: The "American Cures Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The Act includes a cap adjustment provision. The "American Cures Act" includes a cap adjustment provision for biomedical research funding at the National Institutes of Health. The "American Cures Act" sets limits on additional new budget authority for biomedical research funding at the National Institutes of Health for fiscal years 2016 to 2020. The "American Cures Act" limits additional new budget authority for Centers for Disease Control and Prevention funding to $9,149,000,000 for fiscal year 2020 and $11,435,000,000 for fiscal year 2021. The additional new budget authority for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention funding is limited to specific amounts for each fiscal year: $716 million for 2016, $1.287 billion for 2017, $1.503 billion for 2018, $1.98 billion for 2019, and $2.298 billion for 2020. The Department of Defense health program may receive additional new budget authority specified in appropriations bills for each fiscal year, with limits set for each year. The Department of Defense health program may receive additional new budget authority specified in appropriations bills for fiscal years 2017 to 2021, with increasing amounts allocated each year. The Department of Veterans Affairs may receive $540,000,000 in additional new budget authority for the medical and prosthetics research program, with a limit of $25,201,000 for fiscal year 2016. The Department of Veterans Affairs may receive additional new budget authority for fiscal years 2017 to 2021, totaling $25,201,000 for 2017, $52,945,000 for 2018, $80,866,000 for 2019, $112,189,000 for 2020, and $184,027,000 for 2021. The Department of Veterans Affairs is set to receive $184,027,000 in additional new budget authority for fiscal year 2021. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Department of Defense health program will receive additional funding in excess of previous years' amounts. The Department of Defense health program and the Department of Veterans Affairs medical and prosthetics research program will receive increased funding compared to previous years. The 2015 appropriation Act specified funding for the medical and prosthetics research program of the Department of Veterans Affairs, as well as support for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Department of Defense. The Department of Defense health program includes appropriations accounts supporting various institutes, offices, and centers. The medical and prosthetics research program of the Department of Veterans Affairs also has appropriations accounts supporting its various institutes. The Department of Veterans Affairs supports the medical and prosthetics research program through appropriations accounts for various institutes, offices, and centers. This includes funding for the National Institutes of Health. The Department of Veterans Affairs receives funding for its medical and prosthetics research program, including appropriations for the National Institutes of Health. Funding is allocated for fiscal years 2016 through 2021 and subsequent years as needed. The Department of Veterans Affairs receives funding for its medical and prosthetics research program, including appropriations for the National Institutes of Health. Funding is allocated for fiscal years 2016 through 2021 and subsequent years as needed. The amounts provided for each fiscal year shall not be less than the amounts appropriated for fiscal year 2015. Certain appropriations are exempt from sequestration. The American Cures Act amends section 905(g)(1)(A) by adding appropriations for Advances to the Unemployment Trust Fund and Other Funds. This amendment applies to sequestration orders issued under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
